title: Cherries Jubilee (Works for All Types of Cherry)
full_text:

Close
Jump to recipe

10 mins
Cook
10 mins
Total
20 mins
Serves
4 servings

(Keep screen awake)

1/2
cup
granulated sugar
(3 1/2 ounces; 100g)

vanilla bean

or red wine vinegar, or to taste
1

, for serving

1/2
cup
granulated sugar
(3 1/2 ounces; 100g)
One 1-pound (
454
g
) bag frozen pitted sweet
cherries

(60ml) fresh

1/2

(3 1/2 ounces; 100g)
One 24.7-ounce (
700

) jar pitted
sour cherries
in light syrup, drained and 1/4 cup (60ml) syrup reserved
1/4

(60ml) fresh

1 vanilla bean, split, or
1

Pinch

(45ml)

1

cornstarch
stirred into 1 tablespoon water to form a slurry
Vanilla ice cream,
for serving
Directions
If Using Fresh Sweet Cherries
In a 12-inch stainless-steel skillet, combine sugar, water, orange juice, and vanilla and cook over medium-high heat until simmering and sugar is dissolved.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add cherries along with a pinch of salt and orange zest (if using), cover, and cook until cherries are softened and have released their juices, about 4 minutes. Uncover skillet and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until cherries are very tender and caramel has thickened to a glaze, about 4 minutes longer.
Add kirsch (do not pour directly from the bottle if working over an open flame), then tilt pan to ignite the alcohol from a gas burner, or carefully light with a match. Cook, shaking the pan, until the flames have died out and the caramel has thickened to a glaze, about 1 to 2 minutes. Alternatively, you can add the kirsch and not light it on fire, instead simmering until the alcohol has mostly cooked off and the caramel has reached a glaze consistency.
Add vinegar, starting with 1 teaspoon and adding more to taste, if desired, to balance sweetness of sauce. Stir cornstarch slurry to recombine, then add, 1 teaspoon at a time and bringing to a boil between additions, until sauce forms a thickened, honey-like consistency, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat, let cool slightly, then serve with ice cream.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
If Using Frozen Sweet Cherries:
In a 12-inch stainless-steel skillet, combine sugar, reserved cherry juices, orange juice, and vanilla and cook over medium-high heat until simmering and sugar is dissolved.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add drained cherries along with a pinch of salt and orange zest (if using) and cook, stirring occasionally, until cherries are very tender and caramel has thickened to a lightly syrupy glaze, about 3 minutes.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add kirsch (do not pour directly from the bottle if working over an open flame), then tilt pan to ignite the alcohol from a gas burner, or carefully light with a match. Cook, shaking the pan, until the flames have died out and the caramel has thickened to a glaze, about 1 to 2 minutes. Alternatively, you can add the kirsch and not light it on fire, instead simmering until the alcohol has mostly cooked off and the caramel has reached a glaze consistency.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add vinegar, starting with 1 teaspoon and adding more to taste, if desired, to balance sweetness of sauce. Stir cornstarch slurry to recombine, then add, 1 teaspoon at a time and bringing to a boil between additions, until sauce forms a thickened, honey-like consistency, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat, let cool slightly, then serve with ice cream.
If Using Frozen Sour Cherries:
In a 12-inch stainless-steel skillet, combine sugar, reserved cherry juices, orange juice, and vanilla and cook over medium-high heat until simmering and sugar is dissolved.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add drained cherries along with a pinch of salt and orange zest (if using) and cook, stirring occasionally, until cherries are very tender and caramel has thickened to a lightly syrupy glaze, about 3 minutes.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add kirsch (do not pour directly from the bottle if working over an open flame), then tilt pan to ignite the alcohol from a gas burner, or carefully light with a match. Cook, shaking the pan, until the flames have died out and the caramel has thickened to a glaze, about 1 to 2 minutes. Alternatively, you can add the kirsch and not light it on fire, instead simmering until the alcohol has mostly cooked off and the caramel has reached a glaze consistency.
Stir cornstarch slurry to recombine, then add, 1 teaspoon at a time and bringing to a boil between additions, until sauce forms a thickened, honey-like consistency, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat, let cool slightly, then serve with ice cream.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
If Using Jarred Sour Cherries:
In a 12-inch stainless-steel skillet, combine sugar, reserved cherry syrup, orange juice, and vanilla and cook over medium-high heat until simmering and sugar is dissolved.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add drained cherries along with a pinch of salt and orange zest (if using) and cook, stirring occasionally, until cherries are very tender and caramel has thickened to a lightly syrupy glaze, about 3 minutes.
Serious Eats / Jordan Provost
Add kirsch (do not pour directly from the bottle if working over an open flame), then tilt pan to ignite the alcohol from a gas burner, or carefully light with a match. Cook, shaking the pan, until the flames have died out and the caramel has thickened to a glaze, about 1 to 2 minutes. Alternatively, you can add the kirsch and not light it on fire, instead simmering until the alcohol has mostly cooked off and the caramel has reached a glaze consistency.
Stir cornstarch slurry to recombine, then add, 1 teaspoon at a time and bringing to a boil between additions, until sauce forms a thickened, honey-like consistency, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat, let cool slightly, then serve with ice cream.
Make Ahead and Storage
The cherry sauce can be made up to 2 days in advance and refrigerated in an airtight container. Reheat gently; if syrup has become too thick, thin with water if necessary, 1 teaspoon at a time until returned to original consistency. Serve warm over ice cream.
